Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: They appear at a minor hearing where the stakes are relatively low
Story: I glanced at the clock as I snipped the last bit of my regular client’s fringe. She smiled, but then hesitated, “Could you just trim a little more here?” Her tone was gentle, and I knew she trusted me to get it right. I wanted her to leave happy, as always. But my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder for the minor hearing I was due to attend as an advocate in less than half an hour. The case wasn’t high stakes, but my client was counting on me to represent them, to show up prepared and focused. I felt the pressure mounting: the expectation to be present and attentive for my hairdressing client, and the responsibility to advocate effectively in court. My hands trembled slightly as I weighed the minutes, torn between perfecting a fringe and preparing my legal notes. Both clients deserved my best, but I couldn’t give both at the same time. My heart pounded as I tried to decide which role to honor first.
